item.title: .NET Microservices with Steeltoe
item.description:
Steeltoe¬†is an open source framework for .NET that provides libraries to build cloud-native and microservice applications.
In this episode, Cecil chats with David and Hananiel from the Steeltoe project to learn about the various scenarios that it enables for .NET developers.
[01:55] - What is Steeltoe about? [03:31] - How Steeltoe augments existing .NET features? [07:43] - Getting started demo [11:25] - Supporting health checks [16:33] - Distributed tracing and Dynamic logging [21:58] - What other features does Steeltoe support? [27:10] - Azure Spring Cloud for .NET support [28:22] - Learn more about Steeltoe
Get stared https://steeltoe.io/get-started
Steeltoe on GitHub: ¬†https://github.com/steeltoeoss
.NET Microservices: Architecture for Containerized .NET Applications https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/architecture/microservices/?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
Containerized Docker Application Lifecycle with Microsoft Platform and Tools https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/architecture/containerized-lifecycle/?WT.mc_id=ondotnet-c9-cephilli
#aspnet #microservices #dotnet
item.author: (dotNET)

item.title: Azure DevOps Podcast: Derek Comartin on Migrating to .NET Core - Episode 104
item.description: This week on the podcast, Jeffrey Palermo is virtually sitting down with Derek Comartin to discuss migrating to .NET Core!   Derek Comartin is a software developer with two decades of professional software development experience. He has written software for a variety of business domains such as distribution, transportation, manufacturing, and accounting. He is also the Director of Engineering at Full Circle TMS., where he develops transportation management software using a variety of technologies, including .NET. Derek has also founded and currently leads the Windsor-Essex .NET Developers Group, where they explore the use of .NET for building and deploying applications on any platform. On top of all of this, Derek also has a very active blog (CodeOpinion.com) that focuses on CQRS, Event Sourcing, HTTP APIs, and Hypermedia.   In their conversation, Derek tells his migration story and offers pro tips to other developers getting started on theirs.   Topics of Discussion: [:38] Be sure to visit for past episodes and show notes. [:46] About The Azure DevOps Podcast and Jeffrey‚Äôs offer to speak at virtual user groups. [1:49] About today‚Äôs episode with Derek Comartin! [3:03] Jeffrey welcomes Derek to the podcast. [3:16] Derek shares some highlights of his career as well as what he‚Äôs currently up to on a daily basis. [4:38] Discussing the new generation of developers. [5:47] What makes migrating to .NET Core different? And what do developers need to think about if they‚Äôre contemplating migrating? [8:13] Derek details how they migrated their ASP.NET app to .NET Core. [9:57] Derek gives an overview of the system‚Äôs starting point in 2015. [11:32] Derek shares which .NET Framework version they migrated from. [11:55] Why they decided to do all of their prep work while on .NET Framework prior to their migration. [15:59] Derek shares about some of the dependencies that served as challenges during migration and how their team overcame them. [18:08] A word from Azure DevOps Podcast‚Äôs sponsor: Clear Measure. [18:41] Derek continues to share the route that they took with migration. [19:24] Derek shares what their hosting model was at the time vs. what it is right now. [20:15] Are they doing anything currently with Kubernetes? [20:41] About the recent Azure DevOps‚Äô episode with Mike Sigsworth on Kubernetes implementation. [21:38] Is .NET Framework 4.8 all we‚Äôre going to get from Framework? Derek elaborates on their deployment strategy and shares some advice. [26:50] Derek explains why Noda Time should be the standard for communicating over different timezones. [30:32] What levels of test suites did Derek find to be the most helpful with migration? [32:30] Which version of .NET Core are they on now? [32:50] Will they planning a move to .NET 5.0 in a few months or are they going to wait a little while? [33:46] How much CPU, memory, or resources are they using now? [34:51] Derek shares where to find him online as well as some additional resources to check out. [35:46] Jeffrey thanks Derek for sharing his migration story!   Mentioned in this Episode: (Sponsor) ‚Äî Available on Amazon! ‚Äî Click here to download the .NET DevOps for Azure ebook! ‚Äî Follow to stay informed about future events!   Want to Learn More? Visit for show notes and additional episodes.

There is a romance which attaches to the Old Bailey. The name of course means fortified enclosure and it occupies a millennia old footprint on the edge of London‚Äôs [‚Ä¶]

item.title: Why I Link to WayBackMachine Instead of Original Site
item.description: When linking to a page for the purpose of reference, it seems better to me to link to the archive of a given page, rather than to the original site itself. This ensures that after some years have gone by, my article is guaranteed to be consistent. Due the changing nature of the web, there is a chance that after some years, the link could lead to a: 404 / Not Found (most common) Changed or edited content, or entirely replaced content Content that, due to a rise in popularity, is now shielded, demanding the user to make an account to read the entire article.
item.author: (Leo Blanchette)

item.title: Create React App vs Next.js vs Gatsby
item.description:
There are lots of options when building React applications so where do you start? Create React App is probably the most common starting point, but have you looked at Next.js and Gatsby? They are two frameworks built on top of React that bring features like building State Pages, Server Side Rendered Pages, built-in routing, etc.

item.title: DIY IoT door monitor with ESP8266
item.description: Using an ESP8266 for IoT projects makes me go fast while prototyping The compact format is perfect for small DIY devices Wi-Fi connectivity is built-in, and it's super affordable The ESP8266 is a low-cost Wi-Fi microchip, with a full TCP/IP stack and microcontroller capability (wikipedia) Table of Contents tldr; Requirements Circuit explanation Coding Install libraries for ESP8266 Adding the ESP8266 Board Additional libraries Flash it Try it out! Next steps REST API Web UI Demo tldr; The door monitor running in my home activates a buzzer when the proximity sensor detects that the door is opened Additionally, it creates an AP for Wi-Fi configuration using a Web interface, and can connect to a desired Wi-Fi network afterwards
item.author: (Christian Fei)

There are a lot of lessons that web designers can learn from video game user interface design and while they aren‚Äôt always transferrable, they are worth exploring. In this case it‚Äôs the idea of having tooltips within tooltips.

item.title: Tinkerer - You Aren't Going To Need It
item.description: You‚Äôre on a project. You‚Äôre developing an API to count the amount of apples in a cart. You expect to have it done, and people using it in 6 months. Obviously this API needs to be documented, after all you don‚Äôt want your consumers to have to guess how it works. You all agree, that when writing a new endpoint you‚Äôll document it properly. Four months later it‚Äôs looking good - you have a bunch of endpoints that are beautifully documented.

item.title: Before you pack your webapp in Electron | Ori Livni‚Äôs Notes
item.description: Electron has changed the way we create desktop applications. It become very popular among start-ups and enterprises because the ‚Äúeasiness‚Äù of ‚Äúpackaging‚Äù a webapp into an ‚Äúapplication‚Äù. But the fancy dock icon for your webapp doesn‚Äôt come free of challenges, And before you go for this solution you better know a few issues you might encounter, from my experience of 2 years building a shared codebase between a webapp and an Electron app (including native extensions).

item.title: The Business Lessons I Learned from Not Cutting My Hair for 18 Months
item.description:
This is a story of business and determination. What‚Äôs juicy about this semi-private topic is not why I haven't cut my hair for 18 months, but what I‚Äôve learned from going through this process.
What I've experienced along the journey of letting my hair grow are business lessons that at first glance might seem trivial, but that actually reveal some profound answers to our questions about running a successful company.
Let me explain.
